entry.title: Re: Verification of Payee (VoP) - What is planned in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Hi all, I have a basic question about VoP. In SEPA standard the Account Holder name can be long up to 70 digits . The dedicated field in SAP BP masterdata is 60 digits lenght (the field is BUT0BK-KOINH or LFBK-KOINH). If a vendor register a 70 lenght name, using a truncated and shorter name in this field can create a warning or an error from the bank during the VoP check.

Reading the note 2548384 - The length of Account holder name is limited in FK02, seems that SAP won't be adequate for a longer length.

Is it correct? The only alternative is the concatenation of Name1 and Name2 fields to a 70 digits maximum lenght?

Thanks

Lorenzo

entry.title: Adding F4 value help to Custom Business object
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are trying to add an F4 value help to a field in a Custom Business Object (CBO) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
Below are the steps we followed:

  1. Created a CBO A with the required fields.

  2. Created another CBO B, which holds the value help data, and published it.

  3. Created a Custom CDS View using B-CBO as the primary data source and joined it with a standard CDS view.

     Published the CDS view and assigned it as a value help to the field in CBO A.

 

However, when testing the F4 help in the CBO UI, it shows “No data found”, even though data exists in the CDS view.

 

Could anyone please help us understand why the value help is not displaying data, or suggest what configuration might be missing?

 

@SAP SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Extensibility

entry.title: SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management 2511 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
1. Additional Supported Master Data Entities for Company Code Determination (CIM-2637)

With this feature, master data for the entity “Plant” is now supported and can be used to determine the Company Code for supplier invoices. For incoming invoices in which the buyer is a plant in the connected backend system, the plant master data, which includes the plant name and address, can be used to determine the company code. This feature allows for a more accurate company code determination process.

This is important because many organizations operate multiple plants, each potentially aligned to a different company code. Historically, mapping invoices to the right company code in such dynamic environments could be challenging, leading to manual corrections and delays. By incorporating plant master data directly into the automated company code determination process, we are enabling:

  • Greater Accuracy:  Ensures invoices are consistently mapped to the correct entity, minimizing errors.
  • Enhanced Automation:  Reduces manual intervention for company code assignment, saving time for AP teams.
  • Improved Compliance:  Strengthens audit trails and alignment with organizational structures in SAP backend systems.

When a supplier invoice is received, SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management now checks to determine if the invoice was issued to a specific plant. If so, it retrieves the corresponding plant master data and uses this information to map and assign the relevant company code automatically.  This new logic integrates seamlessly with existing backend system connectivity, further optimizing end-to-end invoice processing.

2.  Display of G/L Account, Cost Center, WBS Element Descriptions in Invoice Object Page while in Read-Only Mode (CIM-3080)

With this release, the G/L account, cost center and WBS element descriptions are now displayed on the invoice object page while displaying the invoice in read-only mode.  This provides clarity into essential details of an invoice and makes these details readily available to the user.  As organizations look to streamline their processes, visibility into invoice details remains a priority.  

With this release, users can now view the descriptions for General Ledger (G/L) accounts, cost centers, and Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) elements directly on the invoice object page while in read-only mode. Previously, users only saw technical IDs or codes for these fields, which could require additional steps to understand how invoices were being allocated.

The inclusion of these descriptions brings several immediate benefits:

  • Greater transparency: Users quickly understand the purpose and allocation of costs without navigating away or referencing separate documentation.
  • Accelerated review and approval: Approvers and auditors can immediately verify invoice line allocations, supporting faster decision-making and compliance checks.
  • Reduced user effort and support queries: By displaying clear descriptions for financial objects, you cut down on user questions and misinterpretations.

When you open an invoice in read-only mode within the Invoice Object Page, the G/L account, cost center, and WBS element descriptions will appear alongside their codes, making it easier than ever to understand exactly how each line of the invoice is allocated.

3.  Receive Item Price Details from SAP Business Network (CIM-1360)

With this enhancement, the integration between SAP Business Network and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management has been improved.  You can now benefit from the following additional information, automatically transmitted as part of invoices received through the integration:

  • Tax Codes for Invoices Generated via Purchase Order Flip: Tax codes are now captured and transferred for invoices that suppliers generate by flipping purchase orders into invoices on SAP Business Network. This enables more accurate tax calculation, compliance, and downstream reporting.
  • Commodity Codes at the Line Item Level: Each line item now carries its own commodity code, enabling more granular spend classification and reporting. This makes it easier for accounts payable, finance, and procurement teams to analyze spend by commodity and comply with regulatory or corporate reporting requirements.
  • Charges and Allowances: Additional financial elements such as charges (for example, shipping or handling fees) and allowances (such as promotional or volume discounts) are now included in the invoice data. This ensures that all cost elements are clearly communicated and mapped, reducing reconciliation issues and enabling more precise financial postings.

Customers leveraging the integration between SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management and the SAP Business Network will automatically begin receiving these enriched invoice details for new documents processed after the update. No additional configuration is required —making it easy for your organization to immediately benefit from the improved integration.

4. Creation of Recurring Invoices (CIM-2296)

This new feature enables users to automate and optimize the invoicing process for regular payments for regular payment scenarios such as rent, leases, subscriptions, and other repeat services by creating invoices from existing ones on a scheduled basis. This feature saves time, provides clear identification and tracking of recurring invoices.  It also includes an audit trail for changes. 

Managing recurring payments manually can be time-consuming and error prone. Finance teams often must replicate invoice data or set reminders to issue the same invoice each billing cycle, increasing the risk of mistakes or missed payments. With our new Recurring Invoice feature, these pain points are a thing of the past.

Key Benefits and Capabilities include:

  • Seamless Automation: Users can now schedule the automatic creation of invoices at regular intervals based on existing invoice templates, ensuring timely billing and consistent cash flow management.
  • Efficient Tracking: Each recurring invoice is clearly identified and linked with its original source, providing both transparency and clarity through the lifecycle of the payment.
  • Comprehensive Audit Trail: Every change to a recurring series—whether schedule adjustments or template updates—is tracked for compliance and auditing, bolstering your company’s financial controls.
  • Time Savings: By removing repetitive manual work, your teams can focus on higher-value activities while ensuring billing accuracy and efficiency.
  • Simplified Administration: The new feature offers a centralized view and management capabilities for all recurring invoices making oversight easier than ever.

Getting started is simple. Users select an existing invoice as a template, define the recurrence schedule (for example: monthly, quarterly), and set up automatic generation going forward. Each generated invoice maintains a clear linkage to the original, making it easy to review the series and apply any needed updates.

5. Processing Limit Items (CIM-2296)

As businesses strive for greater agility and control in procurement, flexibility in handling diverse purchase order types becomes essential. With this new feature, you can now process an additional type of purchase order item in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management.  In addition to standard items, you can now also process limit items, which can be of the type material or service.

A limit item is a type of purchase order item that represents goods or services for which the exact quantity and price aren't known at the time of ordering but for which a total budget or spending limit has been defined.

Examples of Use Cases:

  • Ongoing consulting services billed by actual time spent, up to a maximum contract value
  • Maintenance or repair tasks where the extent of work isn’t fully predictable
  • Contingency materials, where you want to cap the amount spent but not specify exact quantities

This means AP teams and procurement professionals gain the following capabilities:

  • Seamless Invoice Processing: Invoices referencing limit items can now be processed directly within Ariba Central Invoice Management, streamlining AP workflows.
  • Greater Flexibility: Accommodate more business scenarios where the details of spending emerge over time, all while maintaining full control and compliance.
  • Enhanced Spend Management: Monitor and manage budgets on limit items to ensure spending stays within defined boundaries.

How Does It Help You?

  • Improved Efficiency:  Reduces manual workaround and off-system processing for variable-scope purchases.
  • Better Compliance:  Enforces contractual budget limits on incompletely specified purchases.
  • Consistent Insight:  Centralizes all PO types in one system for unified reporting and audit trails.

6. New Start and Step Conditions for Approval Workflow (CIM-3138)

With this release, you now have the ability to define start conditions that trigger approval workflows based on specific cost centers or Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) elements within your organization. Moreover, you can also configure these criteria as step conditions within your workflow—helping you direct the right invoices to the right approvers, at the right time.

What does this mean for you?

  • Greater Flexibility: Tailor your approval workflows with precision. For instance, initiate approvals only when invoices are allocated to certain cost centers, or escalate reviews at workflow steps when specific WBS elements are involved.
  • Optimized Control: Ensure compliance with your company’s financial governance by routing invoices for approval only when needed—streamlining processing, reducing bottlenecks, and improving visibility.
  • Adapt to Business Complexity: Easily support complex organizational structures and project-based spending scenarios by making workflows responsive to your evolving finance operations.

This new capability is accessible within your workflow configuration settings in Central Invoice Management. Detailed, step-by-step guidance is available in the release documentation.

7. Viewing Supplier Address Details in Value Help (CIM-3147)

As organizations continue to centralize and streamline their invoice management processes, having rapid and accurate access to supplier information becomes ever more crucial. With our latest Q4 2511 release, SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management takes a significant leap forward in usability with an enhanced feature: Viewing Supplier Address Details.

Based on customer feedback, we’ve expanded the functionality of the Value Help tool in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app. Now, when users select the value help icon for the “Invoicing Party” field—whether on the invoice list or invoice detail pages—they’ll find additional columns in the selection dialog. Alongside the familiar supplier codes and names, you can now view critical address details such as street, house number, and postal code.

With this release, you can now see the following improvements:

  • Quickly distinguish between suppliers or locations with similar or identical names.
  • Reduce errors in invoice assignment and processing.
  • Save valuable time by seeing all relevant supplier address details at a glance, directly within the intuitive value help dialog.

When working in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app, click the value help (search icon) next to the Invoicing Party field. The expanded dialog now displays:

  • Supplier Name
  • Supplier Code
  • Street
  • House Number
  • Postal Code

This enhancement is available in all contexts—the invoice list view and the invoice details page—ensuring consistency and transparency wherever you need to select a supplier.

8. Company Code Determination – Support of Company Name, Address and Supplier Tax Fields (CIM-3168) 

With this feature, additional fields are supported for company code determination. Now, company name, company address and supplier tax will also be used to determine the company codes in addition to the existing fields.

Until now, company code determination in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management relied on a set of established fields to accurately assign incoming invoices to the correct company code in your corporate structure. With the 2511 release, we’re expanding that capability – making it even easier to precisely route invoices based on your unique organizational and tax requirements.

Now, the following additional fields are included in company code determination:

  • Company Name
  • Company Address
  • Supplier Tax

By leveraging these new data points (in combination with your existing rules and fields), you’ll be able to handle more complex company structures and global tax scenarios with greater accuracy.

In today’s dynamic business environment, many of our customers manage a multitude of legal entities, branches, and tax jurisdictions. The correct assignment of company codes is crucial for streamlined, compliant invoice processing and downstream financial reporting.

With this enhancement, you can:

  • Support more nuanced and region-specific business rules for invoices.
  • Reduce manual intervention and the risk of mis-posting.
  • Minimize compliance risks associated with tax reporting and company code allocation.
  • Further automate and harmonize your invoice management processes, regardless of how your business evolves.

In summary, this feature now allows for a more accurate company code determination process.

These updates are designed to empower your invoice management teams with the tools they need. Stay tuned for more enhancements and continue to leverage SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management to drive business success!

Thank you for being part of the SAP Ariba community. We look forward to supporting your journey in delivering exceptional invoice management capabilities.

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link.
  • Resources:
    • Feature related materials
      • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
      • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
    • What’s New

entry.title: [Session Reply & Slides Available] Hot Topic: Joule Activation for SAP Cloud ERP (Public Edition)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Expertise Service Team and SAP AI RIG team recently co-present a deep-dive session focused on enabling ‌Joule‌ - SAP’s generative AI copilot - for SAP Cloud ERP.

The agenda covered as below and feel free to access [Slides] [Recording]. 

  • Business AI capabilities and use cases
  • Joule’s technical architecture on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)
  • Step-by-step activation process for S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Q&A and live troubleshooting

1. Key Objectives‌

  • Demonstrate Joule’s value in streamlining business processes (e.g., sales order management, issue resolution in status check).
  • Guide participants through end-to-end setup using BTP booster, destinations, and identity management.
  • Equip partners to deploy Joule for customers with minimal friction.

2. Business AI & Joule Introduction‌

Joule Definition‌
  • SAP’s generative AI copilot embedded in cloud solutions to automate tasks, provide contextual insights, and reduce manual effort.
Primary Use Case‌:
  • Navigational support (e.g., finding apps without memorizing transaction codes)
  • Transactional support (e.g., creating insights cards, resolving incomplete sales orders)
  • Informational support (e.g., find SAP Help document for relevant business process)
Demo Highlight
  • Create Insights Cards with Joule
  • Check Sales Order Status with Joule‌:Joule identifies incomplete orders, highlights missing fields (e.g., payment terms), and guides users to resolve issues

3. Technical Architecture & Activation Flow‌

3.1 Core Components‌:

  • Joule Web Client‌ is embedded across SAP cloud solutions (e.g., SuccessFactors, S/4HANA)
  • BTP Subaccount‌
    • Hosts Joule instance
    • SAP Build Work Zone
    • connectivity services
  • Cloud Identity Services‌
    • Manages authentication (IAS)
    • Identity / role synchronization (IPS)
  • S/4HANA Cloud APIs‌: Data source for Joule’s responses.

3.2 Activation Steps‌:

Prerequisites‌:
  • BTP global account with Joule entitlements
  • S/4HANA system registered to BTP
BTP Subaccount Setup‌:
  • Create subaccount in preferred region/hyperscaler
  • Assign entitlements:
    • SAP Build Work Zone (foundation or standard edition)
    • Joule service
  • Establish trust to Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Add S/4HANA domain to trusted destinations
Joule Booster Execution‌:
  • Guided setup for BTP formations.
  • Integrate S/4HANA, Build Work Zone, and Cloud Identity Services
Post-Booster Configurations‌:
  • Verify communication arrangements in S/4HANA (e.g., Digital Assistant Service - 0882).
  • Verify BTP Destinations
  • Verify SAP Build Work Zone Content for S/4HANA
  • Configure Identity Provisioning (IPS) to sync users/roles from S/4HANA to Build Work Zone
Validation‌:
  • Ensure Joule icon appears in S/4HANA Launchpad.
  • Test capabilities (e.g., querying open sales orders).

4. Critical Notes & Pitfalls‌

  • Trust Configuration‌: Ensure all solutions in a Joule formation use the ‌same Cloud Identity Services tenant‌.
  • Destination Errors‌: Verify hostnames, client IDs, and secrets in navigation service manually if not auto-generated.
  • Identity Provisioning‌: Ensure IPS jobs run successfully to propagate roles to SAP Build Work Zone.

5. Next Steps & Resources‌

Discovery Center Missions:
  1. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4538/4826/
  2. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4452/4738/
Support Channels‌:
  • SAP Community Blog for slides/recordings.
  • SAP Support for technical errors.
Upcoming Sessions‌:
  • Implement SAP Business AI for SAP Cloud ERP (Oct 27th)
  • Vietnam localization for implementation (Oct 28th)

entry.title: Why clearing SELECT-OPTIONS of time type, which contained a BT interval, becomes EQ 0?
entry.content:
That's a real question, I don't have the answer.

Steps to reproduce:

Create an ABAP executable program with this code:

REPORT zdemo.
SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR sy-uzeit DEFAULT '000000' TO sy-uzeit.

Run the program:

Clear the two fields:

Press Enter:

I would expect to have S_TIME[] empty (it means select any time).

  1. Why one line, why EQ ? (it means select time = 000000)
  2. Did it always work like this?
  3. Is this behavior officially documented (and possibly argumented) somewhere?
  4. What custom workaround could be proposed to the user? (like adding a button to select all, define the screen field as type character and convert to time yourself)

Thanks.

Sandra

My system: ABAP 7.58 SP 1 (on-premises/private cloud)

entry.title: How to Break Down Vendor Amounts While Posting Payroll Results to Finance in SAP HCM
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am encountering an issue during payroll posting to Finance (via PCP0). The system is currently posting the entire vendor-related amount as one summarized line item in the FI document, whereas other salary components are being posted correctly in a separate document.

For instance, the total vendor amount of 53,000 is being combined and posted as a single entry, while Finance requires a detailed breakup of each wage type that hits the vendor account. The expected breakdown should be as follows:

Wage Type Description Amount
1001Solar Loan 8,000
1002Advance Salary20,000
1003Special Loan10,000
1004Vehicle Loan 15,000

Could you please guide me on how to configure the system so that the vendor postings are broken down by wage type rather than being summarized into a single amount?

Any guidance or best practice for achieving a detailed vendor posting structure would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
HCM (Human Capital Management) FIN (Finance)

entry.title: Bridging Your On‑Prem Docker Registry with Kyma: Introducing the Registry Proxy Community Module
entry.content:
Hybrid architectures are the new normal. Yet one persistent friction point remains: securely consuming container images that live deep inside an on‑premise network without punching risky holes in the firewalls or running clumsy mirroring jobs. Today, we’re excited to introduce Registry Proxy - a Kyma community module that lets your cluster pull images from locked‑down, internal Docker/OCI registries while keeping them non‑public.
 
The key benefits of this solution are:
  • Security First: No inbound exposure of your internal registry; all traffic originates inside the cluster.
  • Cost Optimization: Eliminates the need to set up redundant Docker registry infrastructure.

 

Meet the Kyma Community Registry Proxy Module

The Registry Proxy module installs a lightweight operator and controller into your Kyma cluster. It provides a Kubernetes‑native abstraction for defining secure connections to one or more on‑prem registries. Workloads continue referencing familiar image tags; the module handles the secure retrieval path transparently.
 

Powered by SAP Cloud Connector

Under the hood, the module leverages SAP Cloud Connector technology to form an outbound, secure tunnel from the cluster to the on‑prem environment.
 

Defining Connections with a Custom Resource

Connections to internal registries are declared via the Connection custom resource (CR): connections.registry-proxy.kyma-project.io.
 
See the following simple example (illustrative only):
 
apiVersion: registry-proxy.kyma-project.io/v1alpha1
kind: Connection
metadata:
  name: corp-registry
spec:
  registry:
    host: internal-registry.corp.local

 

The operator reconciles this CR, validates reachability through Cloud Connector, and exposes status conditions reflecting readiness and Node Port value to be used when pulling the image. Your workloads then use image references pointing at localhost:{NodePort}/... as if the registry were locally reachable.
 
IMPORTANT: The Registry Proxy module is a community module. Community modules are openly developed Kyma extensions that live outside the core, officially supported module set. They encourage experimentation and early adopter feedback, iterate quickly without waiting for core release cycles, and may graduate to fully supported modules based on adoption and stability.
Expect transparent docs, examples, and active feedback, but remember that community modules are not subject to any service level agreement (SLA). For more information, see Community Modules.
 

Installing the Registry Proxy Module

Installation is streamlined via Kyma CLI, which already supports community modules. Make sure you have the CLI installed.
  1. Run the following command to prepare the module:
kyma module pull registry-proxy --version 0.14.0
       2. Add the module to your Kyma setup:
kyma module add registry-proxy --origin default/registry-proxy-0.14.0 --default-cr

 

Getting Started: Hands-On Tutorial

Ready to try it? Follow the Create Kyma Registry Proxy Connection and a Target Deployment tutorial.

You’ll learn:
  • How to configure SAP Cloud Connector for secure outbound registry access.
  • How to craft and apply a Connection CR.
  • How to deploy a sample workload pulling a private, on‑prem image.
  • How to inspect status conditions to confirm a healthy connection.

Call to Action

Spin up your Kyma environment, install the Registry Proxy community module with Kyma CLI, define a connection, and pull your first internal image securely, without registry exposure. Then tell us what worked, what didn’t, and what you need next.

We invite you to:
  • Open issues for feature requests, edge cases, or bugs.
  • Share deployment stories, such as network topologies and performance observations.
  • Suggest CR field improvements or status semantics.
  • Submit PRs for tests, docs, and example manifests.
  • Go through the tutorial.

entry.title: Expected rating visibility in latest version of PM Form
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

Following the H2 release, we have enabled the latest version of the Performance Management (PM) form to allow visibility of the expected rating and rating gap. However, we’ve observed an issue in Step 1: Employee Assessment  the Expected Rating field appears blank next to the Employee Rating. Interestingly, the expected rating becomes visible when toggling to the legacy version of the PM form.

entry.title: SAP PM enhancement
entry.content:
I had a  requirement : Equipment Master (Transaction IE02 ) Add a new custom view: " additional data” to the equipment master screen layout to accommodate the four custom fields:   

RH Inspection(checkbox), Zone (CHAR field) .These fields will be appended to the equipment master data table EQUI.

Data Propagation

Equipment master to notification

During creation of maintenance notifications (via transaction IW21, notification table QMEL) the custom fields should be inherited from the equipment master by enabling the business scenario EAM_EQUI_TO_NTF.

Notification to work order

When a work order is created from the notification (work orders table AUFK), the custom fields must be transferred from the notification to the work order by enabling the business scenario EAM_NTF_TO_ORD.

entry.title: Re: Why clearing SELECT-OPTIONS of time type, which contained a BT interval, becomes EQ 0?
entry.content:
I got this problem long time ago.

The system's reaction to the default conversion of the TIMS field can also generate this.

  • The system is unable to distinguish an empty field and the time 00:00:00, so unable to remove an empty record.
  • Only contextual menu, right click, allows to remove the initialrecord.

Usually I used a text field with a custom conversion-exit that handle initial text and text with only 0 and : in a different way.

entry.title: Re: SAPCAR cannot be installed Windows 11, version 24H2
entry.content:
The possible reason why SAPCAR cannot be installed or run on Windows 11, version 24H2, even after editing the path variable and issuing the sapcar -xvf <filename> command, is likely due to compatibility issues introduced with the 24H2 update.

Key factors:

  • Windows 11 24H2 introduced breaking changes affecting SAP applications, including SAPCAR and SAP GUI, as reported in multiple support and user forums.

  • Issues include missing executables, inability to launch certain SAP programs, and sporadic failures even when the path variable is correctly set.

  • One confirmed workaround is to uninstall a specific Windows update patch (KB505523) causing the incompatibility, or to wait for SAP to release an updated version/patch that resolves it.​

Additional technical notes:

  • If the PATH variable is set only in the command prompt, it may not persist or be recognized by system-level processes. The correct way is to set it in the Windows environment variable system dialog, ensuring all command prompts see the change.​

  • Some security suites (like CrowdStrike Falcon) may also interfere with SAP executables under Windows 11 24H2.​

Recommended actions:

  • Verify the exact Windows version (winver command).

  • Try running SAPCAR from a command prompt with administrator rights after setting the PATH in the Windows environment variable dialog.

  • If the issue persists and you're on 24H2, uninstall patch KB505523 or pause upgrades to 24H2 until a SAP/SAPCAR update resolves compatibility.​

Summary:
Windows 11 version 24H2 currently causes problems with running SAPCAR and other SAP utilities due to a known software incompatibility introduced in this update, not a path variable error.

entry.title: Interdependencies between date fields in SAPapps “Manage/Create Sales Orders” and “Display Material"
entry.content:
During daily operations with the Manage Sales Orders and Display Material apps, recurring challenges occur due to the logic and dependencies of several date fields. These fields influence each other and can lead to process blockages or require manual intervention when creating deliveries or planning material availability.

Observed Issues

  • Delivery creation is blocked when “Planned Delivery Time” is set too high.
  • Manual adjustments of date fields are often necessary to complete processes.
  • Unclear system logic regarding which date takes precedence or gets overwritten.
  • Lack of transparency in how changes to one field affect others.

Objectives

  • is there any Document for logic and dependencies of the date fields clearly.
  • Do we need to do any improvements in master data (e.g., realistic “Planned Delivery Time” values).

entry.title: Re: Country of Origin for Material
entry.content:
Dear @Dinesh_158,

In S/4HANA Public Cloud the Master Data has a single COO (Country/Region of Origin) field. You will find in Manage Product Master Data->Plant->International Trade

 

That field is for a default value, but it can’t represent multiple simultaneous origins for the same material.

Standard way to handle multiple origins:

Use batch management intended design for materials that can arrive from different origins over time.

How to set it up (S/4HANA Public Cloud)

1. Enable batch management for the product (Manage Product Master Data->Plant-> Batch Management Required.

 

  1. On goods receipt for a PO (Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document), create/assign a batch and fill Country of Origin on the batch.

 

    • The COO is a standard batch attribute (you’ll see it without custom characteristics).
    • You can default or control it via the vendor/PO, but the authoritative value for logistics and export is the batch’s COO.

2. The delivery and export documents will then pick COO from the batch

Summary: Why batches? Because stock, compliance docs, and declarations often need COO at the stock unit level, which varies by receipt.

Reporting by Country of Origin

Depending on whether you need stock, movement history, or compliance views:

Standard reports in Public Cloud:

  • Manage Batches: list and filter batches by Country of Origin; drill into the batch and its quantities/where-used
  • Batch Information Cockpit
  • Stock - Single Material with batch-es

 

  • Material Documents Overview: for example filter by material or batch

 

If you need build analytical report in Custom CDS View app:

1. Custom CDS View, for example data source below:

2. Elements:

 

Recommended path: batches are the cleanest standard

  • If the material can come from different origins: turn on batch management and capture COO per GR at batch level.
  • Use Batch Information Cockpit or Manage Batches for operational views or create your own Custom View.

Best Regards

Dawid

entry.title: Reporting and Analytics
entry.content:
Co-Author: Gergana Deneva; in addition, generative AI was used to help create this content

Elevate Your SAP S/4HANA Experience: We Value Your Feedback!

At SAP,  we're committed to enhancing the reporting and analytics capabilities of SAP S/4HANA to better meet your evolving needs. We are therefore excited to invite you to participate in a customer engagement initiative focused on “Review Booklets and MDA: the next level of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics.”

Why Your Input Matters

Your insights and experiences are invaluable to us. By sharing your requirements and feedback, you help shape the future of SAP S/4HANA, ensuring that our solutions are tailored to your specific needs. This interactive initiative is applicable for both Public Cloud and Private Cloud Edition users.

What's in it for you?

This customer engagement initiative aims to delve into the next level of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics. You will have the opportunity to provide feedback and learn more about the following topics:

  • Review Booklets: Explore the latest innovations in report generation and customization.
  • Multidimensional Data Data Analytics (MDA): Discover advanced analytics capabilities designed to provide deeper insights into your business operations.

Your feedback will help us refine the apps, ensuring they align with the requirements of your business.

How to Participate

We’ve made it easy for you to get involved:

  1. Visit the Influence Page: Go to the campaign page on SAP Influence.
  2. Register: Click on the registration link and follow the simple steps to sign up. Please note that the registration period is open until November 15th.
  3. Provide Feedback: Once registered, you will have access to the platform where you can share your thoughts and requirements.

How you'll benefit

Participating in this initiative brings several advantages:

  • Direct Influence: Your feedback will have a direct impact on the product roadmap.
  • Early Access: Gain early insights into upcoming features and innovations.
  • Community Engagement: Network with other SAP S/4HANA users and share best practices.

Don't Miss Out!

This is your chance to play a pivotal role in the evolution of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics. Your valuable contributions will help us create a more robust and user-friendly platform that meets the diverse needs of our community.

We look forward to your feedback and are excited to collaborate with you on this journey - register now!

Important Dates: Registration Deadline: November 15th

For more information and to sign up, please visit the campaign page.

Thank you for your continued support and partnership. Together, we can drive innovation and create exceptional business solutions.

entry.title: Alternative to "SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR type_t_variable" to avoid buggy "= 00:00:00"
entry.content:
• Problem
  • Workaround
  • Function moduleCONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_INPUT
  • Function module CONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_OUTPUT
  • DDIC domain
  • DDIC data element
  • Program with SELECT-OPTIONS
  • Conclusion

Problem

There is a problem with this code:

REPORT zdemo.
SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR sy-uzeit.

If the user enters an interval:

then clears it:

then press Enter:

it becomes = 00:00:00

which means that only times equal to midnight will be selected.

For all other data types, clearing a SELECT-OPTIONS field means select everything.

I would expect to have S_TIME[] empty (it means select any time).

Workaround

Here is a workaround:

  1. Create a conversion exit ZTIME (two function modules named CONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_INPUT and OUTPUT)
  2. Create a ZTIME DDIC domain of type TIMS (internal length 6, ABAP type T), output length 8, conversion exit ZTIME
  3. Create a ZTIME DDIC data element based on the Z DDIC domain
  4. In your program, use DATA ztime_variable TYPE ztime and SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR ztime_variable.
  5. That's it, there's no more "= 00:00:00" drawback, the whole behavior remains identical to a type T field without ZTIME conversion exit.

The ABAP code below works with ABAP 7.40. If needed, you may convert easily the code to an older ABAP version.

Function module CONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_INPUT

FUNCTION conversion_exit_ztime_input
  IMPORTING
    VALUE(input) TYPE any ##ADT_PARAMETER_UNTYPED
  EXPORTING
    VALUE(output) TYPE any ##ADT_PARAMETER_UNTYPED.

  DATA(ls_table_field) = VALUE tabfield(
      tabname   = 'SY'
      fieldname = 'UZEIT' ).
  CALL FUNCTION 'RS_CONV_EX_2_IN'
    EXPORTING
      input_external               = input
      table_field                  = ls_table_field
    IMPORTING
      output_internal              = output
    EXCEPTIONS
      input_not_numerical          = 1
      too_many_decimals            = 2
      more_than_one_sign           = 3
      ill_thousand_separator_dist  = 4
      too_many_digits              = 5
      sign_for_unsigned            = 6
      too_large                    = 7
      too_small                    = 8
      invalid_date_format          = 9
      invalid_date                 = 10
      invalid_time_format          = 11
      invalid_time                 = 12
      invalid_hex_digit            = 13
      unexpected_error             = 14
      invalid_fieldname            = 15
      field_and_descr_incompatible = 16
      input_too_long               = 17
      no_decimals                  = 18
      invalid_float                = 19
      conversion_exit_error        = 20
      OTHERS                       = 21.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE E054(00). " Check time format
  ENDIF.
ENDFUNCTION.

Function module CONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_OUTPUT

FUNCTION conversion_exit_ztime_output
  IMPORTING
    VALUE(input) TYPE any ##ADT_PARAMETER_UNTYPED
  EXPORTING
    VALUE(output) TYPE any ##ADT_PARAMETER_UNTYPED.

  TRY.
      DATA(time) = EXACT t( input ).
      output = |{ time TIME = USER }|.
    CATCH cx_root ##CATCH_ALL.
      output = input.
  ENDTRY.
ENDFUNCTION.

DDIC domain

DDIC data element

Program with SELECT-OPTIONS

REPORT zdemo.
DATA ztime_variable TYPE ztime.
SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR ztime_variable.

After entering an interval then clearing it, there's no more "= 00:00:00":

 

Conclusion

You have learnt how to avoid the standard "= 00:00:00" drawback, the whole behavior remains identical to a type T field:

  1. Create a conversion exit ZTIME (two function modules named CONVERSION_EXIT_ZTIME_INPUT and OUTPUT)
  2. Create a ZTIME DDIC domain of type TIMS (internal length 6, ABAP type T), output length 8, conversion exit ZTIME
  3. Create a ZTIME DDIC data element based on the Z DDIC domain
  4. In your program, use DATA ztime_variable TYPE ztime and SELECT-OPTIONS s_time FOR ztime_variable.

entry.title: SUM upgrade S/4HANA 2021 to 2023 FPS03 - error MAIN_SHDIMP/SUBMOD_SHD2_RUN/JOB_RSUPG_WRP_SHD2
entry.content:
Dear SAP support,

We're doing a SAP upgrade from S/4HANA 2021 FPS01 to 2023 FPS03.

It's not the 1st system we upgrade in this customer landscape,  but,  this time we have a blocking error : 

Current Phase: MAIN_SHDIMP/SUBMOD_SHD2_RUN/JOB_RSUPG_WRP_SHD2

Last generated error message:
RFC system VS8 nr 02 function 'SUBST_START_BATCHJOB'
RFC failed with code 3 key DBSQL_TABLE_UNKNOWN:
Table is unknown or does not exist.

(Repeat or Initialize the step always fails)

 

In the Shadow System s/n 02,  when SUM phase crashes there's a dump in ST22 : 

"Installation error" :  DBSQL_TABLE_UNKNOWN

Table is unknown or does not exist.

    Error in the ABAP application program.

    The current ABAP program "ZLS_CORE_ZLS_SMOD=============CP" had to be
     terminated because it found a
    statement that could not be executed.

 

As it's on Shadow system,  actions are limited.

As it seems to be linked to Transparent table  "ZLS_SMOD", enhancement implementation "ZLS_BC_BATCHJOB", with customer's validation we would like to "disable" this enhancement but not successfully (system open :  SE03 or SE19 without success or button to change active to inactive ENH is greyed)

We're also not 100% sure it's this table alone, or a more global problem  (another dump in ST22 for another table)

We also don't have access to report ENH_REPAIR_TOOL  as it seems to be available from version S/4HANA 2022...

 

We saw these SAP notes : 

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002148302

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002474180

 

On a side note,  we also could duplicate DDIC user to another user in our Shadow system  (errror = Function parameter "N_SUID_CD_APPLICATION" is unknown)

Before we redo the entire upgrade  (after disabling ENH on main VS8 system),  and without any guarantee,

Thanks a lot for your assistance and knowledge.

Best regards,

 

---->    edit:

solved with commenting the exit code that was reading the table ZLS_SMOD to launch a job   (info from Dev)

SUM continued wit phase RUN_AIMMERGER_UPG_SHD

entry.title: Integrating an Agentic AI LLM with SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis via MCP
entry.content:
Showcase

Context

SAP S/4HANA projects rely on rapid feedback loops, dependable regression testing, clear failure insights, and reusable assets. SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing by Tricentis (ECT) handles the automation part.

What’s been missing is the Agentic layer : enabling your AI to reason about and act within your SAP testing environment.

That’s where the Model Context Protocol (MCP) comes in. MCP is an open standard that enables Large Language Models (LLMs) to securely access tools and data from external systems. With the ECT MCP server, your AI Agent can connect to your tenant and perform real tasks, bringing true Agentic AI capabilities to your SAP ecosystem.

 

Architecture - A bridge between ECT MCP Server and your LLM Agent

In this section, we’ll explore how the LLM Model (OpenAI, Gemini, Claude...) interacts with your LLM Agent (such as Visual Studio Code Chat, Cline or CursorAI) and understand the overall data flow involved in connecting to the Tricentis-hosted MCP server.

Step 1 - You ask your LLM Agent
You type a request in your LLM Agent, for example : "Please give me all the modules and test cases that have been created in the last 30 days."
The LLM Agent forwards this prompt to your LLM model, together with metadata about the workspace, configuration details, and any active MCP integrations.

Step 2 - Your LLM Model calls the MCP tool
The LLM Model analyzes your request, recognizes that the ECT data might be accessible through the connected MCP, and determines the appropriate MCP method to call. In this example : SearchArtifacts.
It builds two queries, called the tool call : one for module artifacts, another for testCase artifacts, both limited to the last 30 days.

Step 3 - Your LLM Agent calls the MCP tool
Your LLM Agent forwards the tool call to a lightweight connector, mcp-remote, which runs locally on your machine and listens on port 56874. The connector then securely communicates with the Tricentis-hosted MCP server via HTTPS.

Step 4 - The MCP handles the job
The Tricentis MCP server handles OAuth authentication, executes ECT queries and actions server-side, and produces structured JSON results (IDs, artifacts, execution logs) for your LLM Agent.

Step 5 - Results flowback to your LLM Agent and Model
The local endpoint receives the response and passes it back to your LLM Agent environment, and then your LLM Model.

Step 6 - Your LLM Model explains the outcome
Finally, your LLM Model interprets the structured returned data and responds in natural language : providing summaries (groups artifacts by type and highlights their creation dates and owners), but also insights or suggested next steps.

Connecting your LLM Agent to the Tricentis MCP Server

Overview

The Model Connection Protocol (MCP) is provider-agnostic : the same hosted MCP server works regardless of where your LLM Model is hosted. Similarly, you can connect from any compatible AI agent interface.

There are several ways to set up your MCP connection. In this guide, we’ll outline two supported options:

Visual Studio Code – In-Editor Chat (GitHub Copilot)

✅Ideal if your organization allows MCP connections in Visual Studio Code ("chat.mcp.enabled": true).

Visual Studio Code – Cline Extension (Standalone UI)

✅Recommended if MCP access is restricted by policy in Visual Studio Code, or if you prefer a dedicated chat agent interface.

Option A - Setup for Visual Studio Code In-Editor Chat (GitHub Copilot)

A.1 Prerequisites

  • Access to your SAP Test Automation by Tricentis tenant
  • Tenant endpoint: https://<tenant>.my-sap.tricentis.com/<WorkspaceID>/_mcp/api/mcp
  • Node.js (required for npx)
  • Local port 56874 available
  • Visual Studio Code with "chat.mcp.enabled": true
Spoiler
To verify this last point, go to the Manage icon Then Settings and search for “MCP”.

A.2 Configuration

Open or create your settings.json file in VS Code.

This file can be managed globally or at the workspace level:

  • Global: %APPDATA%\Code\User\settings.json
  • Workspace: .vscode/settings.json (inside your project)

Add or update the following configuration:

"chat.mcp.enabled": true,
"mcp": {
  "servers": {
    "ToscaCloudMcpServer": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": [
        "-y",
        "mcp-remote@latest",
        "https://<your tenant name>.my-sap.tricentis.com/default/_mcp/api/mcp",
        "56874",
        "--host",
        "127.0.0.1",
        "--static-oauth-client-info",
        "{\"client_id\":\"MCPServer\"}",
        "--static-oauth-client-metadata",
        "{\"scope\":\"tta\"}"
      ]
    }
  }
}

A.3 Reload and Sign-in

Save your changes. If prompted, reload Visual Studio Code, then run your first command (see examples below).
Your browser should open automatically to complete the sign-in process.

You should then see the following message: You can now safely close your browser and return to the Visual Studio Code Chat panel.

Option B - Setup for Visual Studio Code Cline Extension (Standalone UI)

If MCP integration within the in-editor Chat of Visual Studio Code is disabled by your organization, or if you prefer a separate agent interface, you can use Cline with a similar configuration.

B.1 Prerequisites

  • Access to your SAP Test Automation by Tricentis tenant
  • Tenant endpoint: https://<tenant>.my-sap.tricentis.com/<WorkspaceID>/_mcp/api/mcp
  • Node.js (required for npx)
  • Local port 56874 available

B.2 Configuration

In Cline, click the Cline icon:then the MCP Server icon:and Configure MCP Server:

then add or update the following configuration:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "ToscaCloudMcpServer": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": [
        "-y",
        "mcp-remote@latest",
        "https://<tenant>.my-sap.tricentis.com/default/_mcp/api/mcp",
        "--port",
        "56874",
        "--host",
        "127.0.0.1",
        "--static-oauth-client-info", "{\"client_id\":\"MCPServer\"}",
        "--static-oauth-client-metadata", "{\"scope\":\"tta\"}"
      ]
    }
  }
}

B.3 Reload and Sign-in

Save your changes. Run your first command, and complete the browser sign-in process.

You should then see the following message: 

You can now safely close your browser and verify that you see the green dot.

You’re now ready to start interacting with your MCP-connected AI assistant, through Cline.

Interact with your LLM Agent

The Tosca Cloud Model Context Protocol (MCP) integration lets you use natural language to review and manage your test automation tasks. For example, you can ask the AI Agent to create a new test case for a specific flow, move it into a folder, or add it to a playlist, all through simple prompts in your editor.

And honestly, the easiest way to get started… is just to ask the model what it can do!

Conclusion & Next Steps

With just a few lines of configuration, your LLM Agent (whether you’re using VS Code Chat or Cline) connects securely to the Tricentis-hosted MCP Server for SAP Enterprise Continuous Testing. From there, it becomes your operator, able to discover assets, scaffold tests, and analyze runs, all directly from within your development environment.

In an upcoming post, we’ll explore practical examples of prompts and workflows you can try. Give it a spin, experiment, and see what’s possible!

Follow my profile to stay updated when the next article drops, and if you have questions or ideas, join the discussion in the comments.

entry.title: SAP Spend and Finance Point of View: Growth Through Technological Progress
entry.content:
Last week's Nobel Prize announcement included the Economics award to Joel Mokyr, Philippe Aghion, and Peter Howitt for their groundbreaking insights into how technological innovation fuels sustained economic growth. Their research highlights a previously - i.e. only since the industrial revolution - rare phenomenon in human history: persistent economic advancement, fueled by a cycle of innovation and creative destruction. As these economists illustrate, technology plays a pivotal role in elevating global living standards and driving economic progress.

The transformation described by Mokyr, Aghion, and Howitt resonates well with SAP's vision is to help the world run better and improve people's lives with our technology our long history of business innovation.  SAP Spend and Finance Management solutions have an especially rich offering in that regard. Our portfolio embraces the principle of innovation as an enabler of growth. Organizations can leverage our solutions in a number of ways.  For example:  Aghion and Howitt's concept of creative destruction is mirrored in the agile adaptation fostered by SAP solutions. As companies face the inevitable cycles of technological refinement, SAP Spend and Finance Management solutions help organizations manage the conflicts associated with shifting paradigms. By offering tools for strategic decision-making, they enable businesses to navigate the challenges of innovation, ensuring that established practices do not stifle progress.

Three recently announced examples of innovation include:

AI-enabled streamlining and simplification of procurement processes

In today's complex procurement landscape, end-users often face a maze of systems and steps, leading to frustration, delays, and inefficiencies.  Learn how technology can address common intake challenges, such as navigating multiple systems, chasing stakeholder approvals, and ensuring compliance. learn more here

New Levels of Agility and Resilience in Spend Management

Supply shocks, shifting regulations, cost volatility, and talent constraints are constant.  The pressure to deliver more impact is rising, yet resources rarely keep up. Yesterday’s systems weren’t designed for today’s challenges, let alone tomorrow’s which is why we will help our customers leverage the Power of Procurement with Next-Gen SAP Ariba. read more here

Tariff Analysis and Insight​ using value analytics

Underpinned by Intelligent Performance Indicators and populated with ERP data our offering can help customers better understand and manage tariff uncertainty meaning that they can make better decisions faster at the material, plant and location level using lead-time and on-time & in-full and tariff rate metrics. understand more here

In today's fast-paced global economy, the lessons imparted by the 2025 Nobel laureates offer inspiration and guidance. Through the strategic implementation of technologies like SAP Spend and Finance Management, organizations can harness the power of sustained growth and innovation, ultimately contributing to a more prosperous and dynamic future.

entry.title: Mastering Wastewater Compliance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management
entry.content:
Wastewater Management using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management enables a systematic and auditable process to monitor wastewater flows and parameters across your operations.

What is wastewater?

Wastewater is used water from industrial processes (including stormwater) that is no longer clean is categorized as wastewater. In industrial settings, it must be treated onsite or offsite at a publicly operated treatment facility before discharge to the environment.

Why Monitor Wastewater?

In industrial operations, wastewater is among the most tightly regulated environmental media. Regulators require facilities to not only comply with discharge permits but also to maintain robust systems for ongoing monitoring, recordkeeping, and reporting. Effective wastewater monitoring demonstrates proactive management of discharge parameters such as flow, pH, temperature, and contaminant concentrations—ensuring control over both volume and quality.

Beyond compliance, continuous monitoring provides valuable operational insights that help identify process inefficiencies, prevent permit exceedances, and support long-term environmental performance improvements.

Managing Wastewater discharges enables organizations to:
    •    Monitor discharged volumes by area and source 
    •    Evaluate discharge results against legal and internal thresholds
    •    Detect deviations from expected discharge profiles
    •    Support environmental reporting and inspection readiness
    •    Strengthen audibility and data tracking

Wastewater Management features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management:

The solution provides a comprehensive ability to track wastewater outflows, organized by source, time period, and parameter, including:

  • Total volume per discharge point
  • Parameter-specific results
  • Calculation of pollutant loadings
  • Comparison with permitted limits
  • Identification of missing or delayed data
  • Compliance status summaries
  • Permit Management

Benefits

  • Demonstrated operational compliance and license to operate
  • Reduced treatment costs through improved process control
  • Efficient collection of sustainability metrics


Next steps

Use the links below to configure and test the wastewater management functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, EHS environment management.
    •    Step-by-step configuration guide
    •    Standard test scenario with sample data

To follow the full series, subscribe to the SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management tag and stay informed about upcoming publications.

entry.title: Prodction Supply Area is missing in reservation (261)
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

we are using a delivery based Integration between SAP PP and SAP EWM. 

We have maintained a Kanban Control Cycle (PK05), where the IM Storage Location is maintained. Kanban Process works as expected. We have also some products, which are needed less frequent in production, so we use movement type 261 in migo for a consumption against a manufacturing order for these components. 

We have noticed that the delivery generated by this process has the wrong document type in EWM because the two fields HEADER_DATA_SPL-INITIATOR_PROCESS / ITEM_DATA_SPL-SUPPLYAREA in the queue container are empty. HEADER_DATA_SPL-INITIATOR_PROCESS has to be PCD to determine the right ewm document type. ITEM_DATA_SPL-SUPPLYAREA should contain the Production Supply Area. 

We have discovered that the PSA is taken from the reservation into the delivery and the PSA was already missing in the reservation (Table RESB). 


Storage Location 0002 is EWM managed where 7100 is IM managed. We have maintained another Control Cycle for the Supply Area, which we use for Kanban (LPK1) where the Destination Storage Location is IM managend, and the Source Storage Loacation is EWM managed. 

When we maintain Source and Destination Storage Location both 0002 (both EWM managed), then the PSA is taken over into the reservation and the following process is working. 

The Supply Area is maintained in the workcenter (CR03) which is used in the manufacturing order, so actually the Supply Area from the workcenter should be taken over into the reservation, but that did not work right now. 

Is it possible, to use the same Production Supply Area for Kanban and Consumption against Manufacturing Orders (261)? 

Thanks in advance for everyone who is trying to help.

Best regards,
Nicolas

entry.title: C4C Customer Merge Process and SAP ECC
entry.content:
We are looking for recommendations related to the C4C customer merge functionality.

We have SAP ECC and currently replicate Contacts / Accounts between our ERP and C4C. Our service agents frequently create Contacts and Accounts directly in C4C when interacting with customers.

Inevitably, we are left with duplicate Contacts / Accounts every so often. We have scoped the customer merge tool in C4C but are concerned about data inconsistencies.

Further, there are requests to add additional integrations to automate the creation of Contacts into C4C which would then replicate to ERP. Our concern is that the customer merge function is not robust enough or recommended for the level of cleanup that may be required. 

Request:

Please provide recommendations for best practices using the customer merge tool in our case and where the possible implications are when looking at adding additional integrations related to creating new Contacts automatically.
